Graphical abstract Hollow nanostructure of HCS integrates the advantages of CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction. CoS2/MoS2@HCS exhibits strong adsorption capability and catalytic activity, suppressing the shuttle effect and significantly enhancing the cycling stability of batteries. The practical application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries is hindered by the sluggish redox kinetics of sulfur, significant volume expansion, and the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). To address these challenges, this study utilizes hollow carbon spheres (HCS) as a matrix, incorporating a heterojunction of transition metal sulfides (CoS2/MoS2) as the sulfur host. The HCS, with their ultrahigh specific surface area, effectively mitigate structural damage to the cathode caused by sulfur’s volume expansion during charge and discharge cycles. Meanwhile, the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction provides abundant chemical adsorption and reaction sites, which accelerate the redox kinetics of sulfur and alleviating the shuttle effect of LiPSs. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the coupling effect at the CoS2/MoS2 heterointerface significantly enhances charge transfer and adsorption interactions between CoS2/MoS2 and LiPSs. Experimental results demonstrate that Li-S batteries with S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS composites as the cathode exhibit an exceptionally low capacity decay rate of only 0.023% per cycle after 1200 cycles at 2.0 C. Even with high sulfur loading (7.9 mg cm−2) and a low electrolyte-to-sulfur (E/S) ratio (6.0 μL mg−1), the battery achieves an outstanding areal capacity of 6.86 mA h cm−2. This study develops a highly efficient CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction within HCS for the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs, providing valuable insights into the design of high-performance cathode materials for Li-S batteries. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Heterojunction Hollow carbon spheres Adsorption Catalytic 1 Introduction The increasing pressure on fossil energy reserves has accelerated the development of clean energy, thereby intensifying the demand for higher energy densities in energy storage systems [1,2]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have garnered considerable attention due to their high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mA h g−1) and abundant resource availability [3,4]. However, several significant challenges hinder their practical application, including the low electrical conductivity of sulfur and insoluble Li2S2/Li2S, sluggish redox kinetics, the 'shuttle effect' of soluble Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8), and structural degradation of the host material caused by phase transitions during sulfur conversion [5–7]. Notably, accelerating the redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and mitigating the shuttle effect are prerequisites for enhancing the performance of Li-S batteries and promoting their practical deployment [8–10]. Developing cathode materials with high electrical conductivity, large specific surface area, and strong adsorption and catalytic properties is considered an effective strategy to improve the performance of Li-S batteries [11]. Although single carbon-based cathode materials typically possess large surface areas, their interactions with LiPSs are predominantly based on physical adsorption, which fails to effectively suppress the detachment and dissolution of LiPSs [12–14]. This limitation hampers the long-term cycle stability of the batteries. In contrast, the strong chemical interactions between transition metal compounds and LiPSs can accelerate redox kinetics and mitigate the shuttle effect, thereby improving battery performance [15,16]. Furthermore, heterojunctions formed by transition metal compounds with different energy band configurations can optimize electron/ion transfer conditions at the interfaces via the internal electric field generated between the phases, thereby promoting reaction kinetics and ensuring rate performance and long-term cycle stability of the batteries [17,18]. Among transition metal sulfides, MoS2 based on its unique two-dimensional layered structure, offers abundant edge active sites for capturing and accelerating the conversion of LiPSs, in addition to excellent electrocatalytic properties [19]. Compared to MoS2, metallic CoS2 exhibits superior charge transfer capabilities, effectively enhancing the overall conductivity of the cathode material [20]. The heterojunction formed between CoS2 and MoS2 leads to a redistribution of interfacial electrons and the formation of a coupled electric field at the interface, benefiting from the differences in their electrochemical potential and work function. This enhances the interaction between the heterojunction interface and LiPSs [21–23]. Additionally, due to lattice mismatches, the formation of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction is accompanied by new atomic arrangements, defects, or lattice distortions, modifying the band structure of the composites and increasing the density of active site and electron energy state at the interface, which can significantly improve the catalytic performance [24]. Therefore, composites based on porous carbon and transition metal sulfides can not only effectively address the volume expansion caused by the conversion of LiPSs but also provide more abundant active sites to enhance the conversion of LiPSs [25,26]. In this study, a composite of hollow carbon spheres (HCS) loaded with a CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction (CoS2/MoS2@HCS) was constructed and applied as a sulfur host in Li-S batteries. By combining the advantages of the hollow nanostructure and ultrahigh specific surface area of HCS with the benefits of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction, the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite exhibited significantly enhanced sulfur utilization, adsorption capacity, and catalytic activity, along with rapid reaction kinetics under high sulfur loading. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that, compared to single-phase transition metal sulfides, the coupling effect of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction interface effectively enhanced charge transfer between CoS2/MoS2 and LiPSs. This also created a region with high electronic state density at the interface, providing a stronger electron supply for the conversion of LiPSs. Moreover, the altered electronic structure at the interface facilitated the interaction between polysulfide anions and CoS2/MoS2, further promoting the conversion process of LiPSs. Experimental results demonstrated that the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction significantly lowered the reaction energy for the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S, reducing the nucleation energy barrier of Li2S. This effect was attributed to the introduction of abundant defects within the heterojunction and the synergistic catalytic effect between CoS2 and MoS2, which enhanced the adsorption energy of LiPSs while maintaining efficient electron transfer, thus lowering the reaction energy barrier. Benefiting from the hollow structure of HCS and the strong catalytic performance of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction, the Li-S battery with the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite as the cathode exhibited excellent cycling stability. At a test rate of 1.0 C, the battery maintained a reversible capacity of 683.2 mA h g−1 after 1200 cycles, with an average capacity decay rate of only 0.025% per cycle. Under a 2.0 C rate, the average capacity decay rate was 0.023%. Even under high sulfur loading and a low electrolyte-to-sulfur (E/S) ratio, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS cathode retained favorable cycling performance. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Preparation and characterization of CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite The experimental procedure for constructing the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction in HCS via the hydrothermal method is illustrated in Fig. 1 a. Initially, SiO2 was applied as the template, and then coated with a carbon precursor layer (resorcinol–formaldehyde, RF). After thermal annealing, the SiO2 template was removed through NaOH etching to prepare the HCS [27]. The CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite was then synthesized through a hydrothermal reaction. Characterize by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were employed to characterize the prepared composite. As anticipated, the composite exhibited a uniform nanosphere morphology, with no significant changes in morphology or size compared to the original SiO2 template. Meanwhile, the loading of CoS2/MoS2 did not alter the physical structure of the HCS (Fig. 1b). And the synthesized composite retained the uniformity and hollow structure(Fig. 1c). Additionally, CoS2@HCS, MoS2@HCS, and HCS were synthesized and characterized for comparison (Fig. S1). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) revealed the lattice fringes with spacings of 1.80 and 3.10 Å, corresponding to the (200) crystal face of CoS2 and the (110) crystal face of MoS2, respectively (Fig. 1d). The distinct grain boundary interfaces between the CoS2 and MoS2 lattices is further confirmed by the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 1d, inset). Furthermore, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping analysis demonstrated the uniform distribution of Co, Mo, S, and other elements within the CoS2/MoS2@HCS heterojunction composite (Fig. 1e), confirming the composition and uniformity of the composite. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results of sulfur/sulfur host composites showed that the sulfur content in S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS and S@HCS are 68.77% and 67.20%, respectively (Fig. S2). To further confirm the presence of the heterojunction in the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite, the crystal structure and compositional components were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy. The XRD results indicated that the diffraction peaks of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite matched the characteristic peaks of CoS2 (PDF#41–1471) and MoS2 (PDF#37–1492), confirming the successful formation of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction (Fig. 2 a). The properties of the composite were further characterized by Raman spectroscopy, depicted in Fig. S3 and Fig. 2b. The characteristic peaks of CoS2, 1T-phase MoS2 (J 1, J 2, J 3), and 2H-phase MoS2 (E1g, E 2g 1 , A1g) provide additional evidence of the successful loading of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction [28]. Two distinct characteristic peaks at 1341 and 1596 cm−1 were observed, corresponding to the disordered structure (D-band) and graphitic structure (G-band) of graphitic carbon, respectively. The fitted i D/i G peak area ratio for the HCS was calculated to be 0.87, slightly lower than the value of 0.99 for conductive carbon black, indicating a higher degree of graphitization and improved conductivity [29]. Moreover, the i D/i G values of CoS2/MoS2@HCS, CoS2@HCS, and MoS2@HCS were 2.27, 2.17, and 2.15, respectively, suggesting the presence of a significant number of defects in these materials [30]. These defects contribute to an increased adsorption capacity for LiPSs, effectively suppressing the shuttle effect and enhancing the battery performance [31]. Additionally, the presence of defects provides extra space to accommodate the volumetric expansion of sulfur, thereby mitigating structural damage to the electrode and improving cycling stability of the battery. To further investigate the surface properties of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite, its specific surface area was determined through N2 adsorption–desorption measurements. The results indicate that CoS2/MoS2@HCS exhibits a high specific surface area of up to 1240.72 m2 g−1 (Fig. 2c). This large specific surface area not only mitigates the structural damage to the electrode material caused by the volumetric expansion of sulfur during charge and discharge cycles processes but also enhances sulfur utilization. Moreover, it facilitates the infiltration of the electrolyte, thereby promoting the transport rate of lithium-ion and electrons within the electrode material. Additionally, the increased surface area provides more active sites for adsorption and catalysis, which strengthens the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs, ultimately improving the rate performance and cycling stability of Li-S batteries [32]. When sulfur is loaded onto the host material, it infiltrates and partially fills the pores of the material, substantially reducing the specific surface area of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite to 76.66 m2 g−1 (Fig. S4). The test results show that sulfur mainly fills the pore structure of the support material, and the rich pore structure can effectively limit the dissolution of LiPSs. The elemental composition and electronic configuration of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite were further investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The characteristic peaks of specific elements observed in the full-scan spectrum confirm the successful synthesis of the composites (Fig. 2d). In the high-resolution C 1s spectrum of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite, the peaks at 284.8, 285.5, 286.3, and 288.3 eV correspond to C–C, C–N, C–O, and C=O bonds, respectively (Fig. S5) [33]. The Mo 3p and N 1s spectra were primarily deconvoluted into characteristic peaks associated with Mo 3p (395.3 eV), pyridinic N (398.8 eV), graphitic N (401.5 eV), oxidized N (403.0 eV), and Mo–N (402.1 eV) (Fig. 2e) [34,35]. Notably, the overlap between the Mo 3p and N 1s spectra indicates an interaction between Mo atoms in the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction and N atoms in the HCS framework. This interaction enhances the tendency of electron transfer from Mo atoms, significantly increasing the oxidation state of the Mo element. High-valence Mo atoms introduce more unoccupied d orbitals, facilitating electron exchange with LiPSs. Furthermore, high–valence Mo atoms can reduce charge transfer resistance at the interface and accelerate lithium-ion diffusion within the battery, thereby delivering superior electrochemical performance. The high-resolution S 2p spectrum revealed peaks corresponding to S 2p 3/2 (162.1 eV) and S 2p 1/2 (163.5 eV) associated with the 1T-phase, as well as peaks at 163.2 and 164.6 eV were assigned to S 2p 3/2 (2H) and S 2p 1/2 (2H), respectively (Fig. 2f) [36]. Using density functional theory (DFT), the energy band structure, charge density difference, and adsorption energy with LiPSs were simulated to investigate the interfacial interaction mechanisms between various electrode materials and LiPSs. The optimized catalyst structure is shown in Fig. S6. The projected density of states (PDOS) and band calculation results indicate that materials loaded only with MoS2 exhibit typical semiconductor characteristics, with relatively poor electronic conductivity (Fig. 2g). In contrast, CoS2 materials demonstrate higher PDOS peaks at the Fermi level and energy bands crossing the Fermi level, reflecting their metallic properties (Fig. 2h). Notably, the energy bands of CoS2/MoS2 and CoS2 overlap at the Fermi level, indicating strong metallic characteristics and excellent electronic conductivity (Fig. 2i) [24,37]. After the heterojunction forms, the energy band structure of the composite undergoes significant changes, with the orbital energy levels of Mo shifting downward. This change originates from electronic coupling effects at the interface between CoS2 and MoS2, as well as the redistribution of interfacial charges, which further alters the local electronic structure of Mo atoms and lowers their orbital energy levels [38]. Furthermore, compared to CoS2 and MoS2, the CoS2/MoS2 composite exhibits a narrower bandgap between the valence band maximum and conduction band minimum, along with a higher electron density near the Fermi level, suggesting improved charge transport capability [39]. 2.2 Polysulfides adsorption, catalytic conversion, and theoretical calculation The shuttle effect in Li-S batteries primarily involves the dissolution of long-chain LiPSs (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) into the electrolyte, followed by their migration to the anode where they react with lithium [40]. This process leads to energy loss and reduces the cycling stability of the battery. The key to improving battery performance lies in enhancing the adsorption of LiPSs, thereby inhibiting their shuttling. In this study, composites were immersed in bottles containing a 0.5 mM Li2S6 solution to evaluate the adsorption ability of different sulfur host materials toward LiPSs. The evaluation was based on both the color change of the solution and UV–vis absorption spectra (Fig. 3 a, inset). After standing for 24 h, the solution in the bottle containing the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite appeared nearly transparent, indicating its optimal chemical affinity for Li2S6. UV–vis spectroscopy analysis of the supernatant after standing revealed results consistent with the visual adsorption observations (Fig. 3a). The UV–vis absorbance of the solution after adsorption by the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite was significantly lower than that of other materials, indicating stronger interactions with LiPSs and a superior ability to capture them. This prevents LiPSs from easily dissolving into the electrolyte, thereby more effectively suppressing the shuttle effect during the charge/discharge process of the battery. To further confirm the interaction between the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite and LiPSs, XPS spectroscopy was employed to characterize the composite before and after the adsorption of Li2S6. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of the composite prior to adsorption revealed characteristic peaks of Co2+ and Co3+, with binding energies of 779.7 and 782.0 eV, respectively, indicating different states of Co on the surface of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite (Fig. 3b) [41]. After the adsorption of Li2S6, due to charge transfer between CoS2/MoS2@HCS and Li2S6, the electron cloud on the material’s surface underwent rearrangement, leading to an increase in local electron density. This caused a shift in the Co 2p characteristic peaks toward lower binding energies, further verifying the strong chemical interaction between CoS2/MoS2@HCS and Li2S6. The Mo 3d XPS spectrum could be deconvoluted into four main peaks, with characteristic peaks at 229.2 and 232.3 eV corresponding to Mo 3d 5/2 and Mo 3d 3/2, respectively (Fig. 3c) [42]. The peak at 226.8 eV was attributed to S 2s, confirming the presence of MoS2 [43]. Additionally, the characteristic peak at 236.5 eV corresponded to Mo6+ 3d 3/2, which was primarily attributed to the interaction between Mo atom and N atom, resulting in an increased valence state of Mo, consistent with the XPS results [35,36]. Notably, after the adsorption of Li2S6, a significant negative shift was also observed in the Mo 3d spectrum. The XPS results indicate that both Co and Mo elements in the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite participate in the anchoring and catalytic conversion processes of Li2S6. To better elucidate the interactions between host materials and LiPSs in terms of molecular structure and electron transfer, DFT calculations were employed to simulate the charge transfer between LiPSs of varying chain lengths and several composites (Fig. 3d, Figs. S7 and S8). The computational results reveal significant electron accumulation at the interfaces of the host materials, primarily attributed to the strong electronic interactions between the host materials and LiPSs, which further enhance the affinity for Li+ in the LiPSs [44]. The combination of CoS2 and MoS2 results in a rearrangement of the electronic structure, forming a localized electric field at the heterojunction interface. Stronger electron transfer and higher electron cloud density were observed in the CoS2/MoS2-LiPSs system, indicating that the CoS2/MoS2 composite exhibits stronger electronic coupling effects, thereby accelerating charge transfer between CoS2/MoS2 and LiPSs [45]. Furthermore, based on the optimized adsorption models, theoretical calculations of the binding energies between different sulfur host materials and LiPSs were conducted to further explore their interactions (Figs. S9–S11). Compared to CoS2 and MoS2 alone, the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction exhibits the highest binding energy with various sulfides, corresponding to a stronger anchoring capability for LiPSs (Fig. 3e). This is mainly due to the strong interactions between both CoS2 and MoS2 with LiPSs, which readily form Co–S and Mo–S bonds with sulfur atoms during the reaction process [46]. The stronger anchoring ability effectively suppresses disproportionation reactions, mitigates the dissolution of LiPSs in the electrolyte, and reduces the shuttle effect. The Gibbs free energy evolution diagram for the transformation from the initial material S8 to the discharge end product Li2S was simulated to evaluate the catalytic activity of various sulfur host composites in the LiPSs conversion process (Fig. 3f). During the reduction of long-chain LiPSs (Li2S8) to Li2S4, the conversion step from Li2S8 to Li2S6 exhibits a more significant thermodynamic barrier, indicating that the former step is the rate-determining step in the liquid–liquid conversion process. The CoS2/MoS2 composite material demonstrates the lowest energy barrier (0.58 eV) in this process, indicating its high catalytic activity for this conversion. Meanwhile, in the liquid–solid conversion process of reducing Li2S4 to Li2S2 and Li2S, the reduction step from Li2S4 to Li2S2 is the rate-determining step. At this stage, the energy barrier for the CoS2/MoS2 composite material is 0.59 eV, which is significantly lower than that of CoS2 (0.95 eV) and MoS2 (1.15 eV) single materials. In the CoS2/MoS2-LiPSs system, the energy barriers required for each conversion step are significantly lower than those for the CoS2-LiPSs and MoS2-LiPSs systems, indicating that it is more likely to undergo a thermodynamically more favorable reduction process. The high conductivity of CoS2 and the excellent chemical stability of MoS2 exhibit a synergistic effect in the composite, forming a localized electric field at the interface of the composite and significantly reducing the band gap through electronic structure reorganization. This heterojunction structure markedly increases the density of active sites at the interface, enabling more effective capture and conversion of LiPSs and preventing the dissolution of intermediates and side reactions. Additionally, the electron and ion transfer rates at the interface are optimized, further lowering the free energy for the conversion reactions, thereby facilitating the smooth transformation of LiPSs and accelerating the reaction kinetics. The lithium-ion (Li+) migration energy barrier is a critical factor affecting the ionic conductivity, rate performance, and cycle life of Li-S batteries. CoS2 exhibits metallic properties, providing efficient electron transport channels, while MoS2, due to its two-dimensional layered structure, demonstrates excellent Li+ diffusion performance. The CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction combines the superior electronic and ionic conductivity of both materials. Furthermore, the strong synergistic effect at the interface of the heterojunction significantly reduces the Li+ migration energy barrier, effectively facilitating Li+ diffusion and migration. Compared to the individual sulfur host materials of CoS2 (0.95 eV) and MoS2 (1.15 eV), the energy barrier for Li+ migration at the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction interface is significantly lower (0.59 eV). This indicates that the diffusion energy gradient of Li+ at the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction interface is remarkably optimized, favoring Li+ diffusion and migration (Fig. 3g and Fig. S12). This phenomenon is primarily attributed to charge redistribution, increased active sites, and optimization of diffusion pathways at the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction interface. These synergistic effects collectively lower the migration energy barrier and enhance Li+ diffusion efficiency [20,28]. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was employed to fabricate symmetric batteries using Li2S6 as the electrolyte, aiming to investigate the catalytic activity of various electrode materials. Compared to CoS2@HCS, MoS2@HCS, and HCS electrodes, the symmetric battery employing CoS2/MoS2@HCS as the electrode exhibited multiple distinct oxidation and reduction peaks, indicating rapid and well-defined redox reactions of LiPSs during charge/discharge cycles (Fig. 4 a) [47]. This phenomenon demonstrates that the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction possesses superior electronic and ionic conductivity and abundant active sites, facilitating faster redox reaction rates. Consequently, the symmetric battery displays more pronounced and well-defined redox peaks, with significantly increased peak currents. As the scan rate increases, the oxidation and reduction peaks remain clearly defined, indicating that CoS2/MoS2@HCS continues to exhibit high catalytic conversion efficiency for LiPSs even under intensified charge/discharge conditions (Fig. 4b) [24]. To further evaluate the role of different electrode materials in promoting the conversion kinetics of LiPSs, Tafel analysis was conducted to reveal their catalytic activity. The exchange current density (I o) derived from Tafel plot fitting showed that, during oxidation and reduction processes within the battery, the CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery achieved the highest I o value of 11.07 × 10−2 mA cm−2, compared to 8.57 × 10−3 mA cm−2 for CoS2@HCS, 5.84 × 10−3 mA cm−2 for MoS2@HCS, and 1.82 × 10−3 mA cm−2 for HCS (Fig. 4c). The higher exchange current density is attributed to the synergistic effect between CoS2 and MoS2, which enhances the catalytic activity at the electrode interface and improves the efficiency of charge transfer during reactions. The combined effect of these factors promotes the reversible conversion of LiPSs, thereby accelerating the redox reaction kinetics [48]. Chronoamperometry curves of the symmetric batteries further confirm the catalytic performance of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite for LiPSs. Among the symmetric batteries with different electrode materials, the CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery exhibited the highest current response in its chronoamperometric curves, indicating that the loaded CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction significantly enhances the electron/ion transfer rate within the battery while promoting the catalytic conversion kinetics of LiPSs (Fig. 4d) [49]. It is noteworthy that the current response of symmetric batteries using Li2S6 as the electrolyte was significantly higher than that of batteries without Li2S6. This phenomenon suggests that the current response is primarily governed by the redox reactions of Li2S6 rather than by double-layer capacitive effects [17,50]. The performance of various electrode materials in facilitating redox reactions was evaluated through CV curves. When compared to S/CoS2@HCS, S/MoS2@HCS, and S@HCS cathode materials, the battery incorporating S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS as the cathode exhibited a lower oxidation potential and a higher reduction potential (Fig. 4e). This phenomenon indicates that the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite enables more efficient charge transfer during redox reactions, thereby reducing energy loss during the reaction process, enhancing the electrochemical reversibility of the reactions, and effectively promoting the conversion of LiPSs (Fig. 4f) [51]. Moreover, the synergistic effect of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction, which provides more abundant electron and ion transport pathways, and the conversion efficiency of LiPSs is significantly improved while optimizing the electron/ion transfer processes. As a result, the peak current of the redox peaks for the Li-S battery with the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS as the electrode is noticeably higher than that of the other materials (Fig. S13) [52]. Further analysis of the Tafel slope derived from the CV curves of different cathode materials revealed that the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery exhibited the smallest slope during both oxidation and reduction processes. This finding suggests that the material provides more chemically active sites and reduces the reaction energy barrier through its unique interfacial effects (Fig. 4g) [53]. Additionally, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS battery demonstrated more stable cycling characteristics in the multi-cycle CV curves, indicating that the stable presence of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction contributes to enhancing the reversibility of the internal reactions within the battery (Fig. S14). The catalytic activity and enhanced reaction kinetics of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS electrode material were revealed through electrochemical testing. In the contour plots of CV at different scan rates (0.1–0.5 mV s−1), distinct reduction peaks near 2.0 and 2.3 V were observed in the Li-S battery due to the transformation of insoluble S8 into soluble long-chain LiPSs, followed by their further conversion into insoluble Li2S2/Li2S (Fig. 4h and Fig. S15) [8,54]. Furthermore, the oxidation process of Li2S2/Li2S was significantly accelerated by the presence of CoS2/MoS2, CoS2, and MoS2, enabling an efficient conversion of Li2S2/Li2S back into long-chain LiPSs and ultimately oxidizing them to S8. In comparison with the S@HCS-based battery, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS, S/CoS2@HCS, and S/MoS2@HCS batteries exhibited two distinct split peaks during the oxidation process (Fig. S16). The acceleration of conversion kinetics indicates that the stronger conductivity and more abundant active sites significantly increase the redox reaction rate of LiPSs, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of the battery. Notably, as the scan rate increased, the two split oxidation peaks maintained their clearly defined shapes, further demonstrating the strong catalytic capability of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS electrode material [24]. The diffusion rate of Li+ ( D Li + ) during the charge/discharge cycles of the Li-S battery is a key factor influencing the conversion kinetics of LiPSs, determining the utilization of active materials in the electrode and the rate performance of the battery device. According to the Randles-Sevcik equation, the peak current in the CV curve exhibits a linear relationship with the square root of the scan rate, while the slope of the fitted linear relationship is positively correlated with the Li+ diffusion rate [55]. The results showed that, compared to the other electrode materials, the fitted curve of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS battery was steeper, corresponding to a larger slope and a higher D Li + . This indicates faster and more efficient Li+ diffusion behavior, effectively promoting the electrochemical conversion reactions of LiPSs (Fig. 4i-k and Figs. S17 and S18). The overpotential required for the second platform during the charge/discharge process is widely used to evaluate the catalytic performance of different electrode materials in the conversion of LiPSs [56]. The charge/discharge behavior of the batteries was investigated through galvanostatic charge/discharge curves. Benefiting from the excellent electronic conductivity and optimized interfacial structure of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS heterojunction material, the Li-S battery with S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS as the cathode material exhibited the smallest decomposition and deposition overpotentials for Li2S, effectively enhancing the conversion kinetics of LiPSs (Fig. 5 a and Fig. S19). Typically, the capacity ratio of the high-voltage platform (Q H) to the low-voltage platform (Q L) during discharge is used as a standard to assess the sulfur conversion efficiency within the battery system. Q H represents the reduction of S8 to soluble LiPSs, while Q L represents the reduction of soluble LiPSs to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S [57]. Under ideal conditions, when S8 is fully converted to Li2S during discharge, Q H and Q L account for 25% and 75% of the total capacity of the Li-S battery, respectively, corresponding to a Q L/Q H value of 3 [58]. The S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS battery exhibited the highest Q L proportion of 72%, with a Q L/Q H value as high as 2.57, surpassing the values for Li-S batteries using S/CoS2@HCS (70%, 2.33), S/MoS2@HCS (68%, 2.13), and S@HCS (67%, 2.03) as cathode materials (Fig. 5b and Fig. S20). This phenomenon indicates that CoS2/MoS2@HCS, as a sulfur host material, demonstrates superior catalytic activity in promoting the conversion of LiPSs, while simultaneously enhancing sulfur conversion kinetics and improving sulfur utilization [59]. Higher sulfur utilization and optimized sulfur conversion kinetics effectively mitigate the dissolution and migration of LiPSs in the electrolyte, thereby suppressing the shuttle effect. The nucleation and dissolution process of Li2S serves as a critical reference for evaluating the adsorption/desorption capacity of sulfur host materials, interfacial charge transfer rates, and catalytic activity for the conversion of LiPSs in Li-S batteries. Potentiostatic intermittent titration technique (PITT) was employed to investigate the nucleation and dissolution reactions of Li2S, revealing the catalytic performance of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction for LiPSs conversion (Fig. 5c and Fig. S21) [60]. The Li2S deposition capacity of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS electrode was the highest, reaching 229.05 mA h g−1, which is significantly higher than that of CoS2@HCS (166.78 mA h g−1), MoS2@HCS (130.81 mA h g−1), and HCS electrodes (115.97 mA h g−1). Furthermore, the high specific surface area and abundant interfacial active sites of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite jointly facilitated rapid charge transfer and catalytic conversion of LiPSs within the system [61]. These results indicates that the CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery achieves the highest peak response current (0.90 mA), the fastest deposition rate (500 s), and a more homogeneous Li2S deposition morphology (Fig. S22). Through PITT studies, it was discovered that the dissociation kinetics of Li2S are essentially consistent with its nucleation process. The CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite material accelerates the response time for Li2S dissolution, exhibiting the highest dissolution capacity and the least Li2S residue (Figs. S23 and S24). These findings indicate that the heterojunction composed of CoS2 and MoS2 not only enhances Li2S nucleation efficiency but also optimizes its dissolution process, thereby exerting a bidirectional catalytic effect. The electrochemical performance of various cathode batteries was evaluated using the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) [62]. During the nucleation and dissolution of Li2S, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS cathode exhibited the lowest activation voltage compared to the other electrode materials (Fig. 5d and Fig. S25). In addition, the internal resistance (IR) during the charge and discharge process of the Li-S battery was calculated using Eq. [S8], which corresponds to the interconversion of LiPSs [63]. During discharge, as the poorly conductive solid S8 initially transforms into the more conductive and soluble LiPSs, the internal resistance of the battery decreases. However, as the conversion process progresses, the viscosity of the electrolyte gradually increases due to the accumulation of LiPSs, which impedes ion transport in the electrolyte and causes an increase in internal resistance. Subsequently, during the conversion of soluble LiPSs to insoluble Li2S, accompanied by the consumption of LiPSs, the internal resistance of the battery exhibits a trend of initially decreasing and then increasing. This is attributed to the reduction in electrolyte viscosity and the formation of insulating Li2S [64]. A reversed trend is observed for the internal resistance during the charging process. The calculation results indicate that the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery exhibits the lowest internal resistance (Fig. 5e). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves further corroborate this result. Compared to the S/CoS2@HCS (65.80 Ω), S/MoS2@HCS (84.55 Ω), and S@HCS (115.94 Ω) batteries, the battery with the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS as cathode has the smallest charge transfer resistance (Rct) of 53.40 Ω (Fig. 5f). Additionally, it possesses the lowest intrinsic resistance within the electrode and at the interface (Fig. S26). This is due to the formation of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction, which enhances the conductivity of the electrode material, effectively improving the charge transfer and Li+ diffusion kinetics within the battery [65]. After cycling, the impedance of the battery significantly decreases, and an additional semicircle appears in the high-frequency region for all batteries, which was attributed to the formation of an insoluble Li2S2/Li2S passivation layer on the surface of the lithium anode during cycling (Fig. S27). To investigate more clearly the suppression effect of different sulfur host materials on the LiPSs shuttle effect, in-situ Raman spectroscopy was used to monitor the discharge process of the Li-S battery [66]. A 532 nm laser passed through the observation window of the in-situ Raman setup and a small hole in the lithium foil to irradiate the separator, thereby detecting the characteristic peaks of LiPSs that shuttle from the cathode side to the anode side (Fig. 5g). The intensity of the characteristic peaks effectively reflects the electrode material’s suppression of LiPSs. For the Li-S battery with S@HCS as the cathode, during the initial discharge stage, the internal S8 quickly transforms into soluble Li2S8 (170.52, 209.13, and 494.74 cm−1), and as the discharge progresses, the dissolved LiPSs in the electrolyte gradually diffuse to the anode side (Fig. 5h and i). Throughout the discharge process of the battery, Li2S8, Li2S6 (399.42 cm−1), Li2S3 + Li2S4 (416.33 cm−1), and Li2S4 + Li2S5 (455.63 cm−1) coexist, indicating that the conversion of LiPSs in the electrolyte is slow, and a significant LiPSs shuttle effect exists within the battery [67]. Notably, for the electrode loaded with CoS2/MoS2 heterojunctions, the Raman signals of LiPSs during the discharge process are relatively weak, with only trace amounts of Li2S8 and Li2S6 detected as the electrolyte diffuses to the anode side due to the concentration gradient (Fig. 5j and k). The comparative in-situ Raman results indicate that the introduced CoS2/MoS2 heterojunctions exhibit strong adsorption and catalytic conversion effects on soluble LiPSs, effectively suppressing the shuttle effect and reducing the irreversible loss of sulfur active species. 2.3 Electrochemical properties and comparison of Li-S batteries The rate capability and charge/discharge curves of the battery are important references for evaluating the performance of sulfur host materials in Li-S batteries. The test results reveal that the reversible capacities of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based Li-S battery at current rates of 0.1 C, 0.2 C, 0.5 C, 1.0 C, 2.0 C, and 5.0 C are 1279.7, 1108.5, 979.5, 891.9, 818.1, and 648.5 mA h g−1, respectively. This indicates that the battery retains good capacity retention even under high-rate conditions. Even when the test current is restored to 0.1 C, the specific capacity of the battery recovers to 1088.5 mA h g−1 with no significant degradation, which is notably superior to the other sulfur host materials (Fig. 6 a). The excellent reversible capacity and high-rate performance suggest that the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based Li-S battery achieves the highest active sulfur utilization rate. Although the overpotential of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery gradually increases with the increase in test current, even under the high test current condition of 5.0 C, the discharge plateau corresponding to the conversion of S8 to soluble LiPSs and further reduction to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S remains well-maintained (Fig. S28). This demonstrates that even under high-rate charge/discharge conditions, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS battery is able to maintain a stable sulfur conversion process without significant performance degradation. This phenomenon is attributed to the synergistic interactions within the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction, which suppress the occurrence of irreversible side reactions during the LiPSs conversion process at the heterogeneous interface. By enhancing charge transfer at the interface and optimizing the internal reaction kinetics, the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction significantly reduces the energy loss caused by overpotential, thereby maintaining stable charge/discharge performance under high-rate conditions. The long-term cycling performance of Li-S batteries directly reflects the impact of sulfur host materials on the stability of the battery. Long-term cycle test results for batteries with various electrode materials under 0.5 C conditions show that the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery exhibits the highest initial discharge capacity of 1128.5 mA h g−1, and maintains a high capacity of 805.2 mA h g−1 after 800 cycles, which is significantly higher than that of the S/CoS2@HCS (668.0 mA h g−1), S/MoS2@HCS (526.5 mA h g−1), and S@HCS (415.1 mA h g−1) batteries (Fig. 6b). The synergistic effect of CoS2 and MoS2 enhances charge transfer and reaction kinetics, resulting in remarkable capacity retention. The battery’s cycling performance is enhanced by the suppression of the LiPSs shuttle effect. Even after 800 cycles, the constant current charge/discharge curves of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery still display two distinct discharge voltage platforms, with negligible increase in polarization voltage (Fig. 6c). Fig. S29 presents the SEM image of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS cathode after cycles. The image reveals that the electrode structure remains intact, with no obvious surface cracks. This indicates that the volume expansion of sulfur during the cycle has little effect on the overall structure of the electrode, demonstrating the excellent structural stability of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite. Furthermore, the long-term cycle stability of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery was investigated under high current conditions. At a current of 1.0 C, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS battery demonstrates a high initial capacity of 979.2 mA h g−1, which remains at 683.2 mA h g−1 after 1200 cycles, with an exceptionally low capacity decay rate of 0.025% per cycle (Fig. 6d). The excellent performance is mainly attributed to the robust volumetric expansion buffering ability provided by HCS and the efficient adsorption and catalytic effect of CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite on soluble LiPSs. Further tests reveal that thanks to the high sulfur utilization and outstanding catalytic effects of the CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite, the battery achieved high initial areal capacities of 3.77, 5.21, and 6.86 mA h cm−2 when the sulfur load was 3.4, 5.2, and 7.9 mg cm−2, respectively (Fig. 6e). After 100 cycles at 0.1 C, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based Li-S battery, with a high sulfur load of 7.9 mg cm−2, still maintained an areal capacity of 6.12 mA h cm−2, which is superior to the 4 mA h cm−2 of commercial lithium-ion batteries [68]. Due to its exceptional adsorption and catalytic properties, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery maintains a stable voltage even after 72 h of rest (Fig. 6f). This stability suggests that the modified cathode material effectively inhibits the permeation of LiPSs and mitigates the self-discharge phenomenon (Fig. S30). In comparison with recent literature reports on Li-S batteries with CoS2 and MoS2 sulfur host, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based battery demonstrates strong competitiveness in terms of cycle life, test current, and capacity retention (Fig. 6g and Table S1), for the following reasons [69–76]. First, the extremely large specific surface area provides multiple channels for the electrolyte to penetrate from the surface to the interior, shortening the diffusion paths of ions and electrons, while buffering volumetric changes during the charge/discharge process. Secondly, compared to existing sulfur host materials reported in the literature, under the synergistic effect of CoS2 and MoS2, the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS composite offers more redox reaction active sites, significantly enhancing the catalytic conversion performance. Additionally, soft-pack batteries using S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS as the cathode were prepared to evaluate the potential of the S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS cathode in practical applications. The S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS-based soft-pack battery successfully powered a fan, demonstrating its practical application capability (Fig. 6h). The performance test results show that the unique synergistic effect of the hollow structure and the heterojunction significantly improves the electrochemical performance of the battery. The hollow structure with an ultra-large specific surface area shortens the Li+ transport distance, facilitates efficient electron transfer, and provides ample space to buffer substantial volume changes during the reaction process, thereby ensuring the structural integrity of the electrode materials during the charge/discharge process. The interfacial electronic coupling interactions at the heterojunction alter the electronic structure and charge distribution at the interface, promoting the redox reaction kinetics of LiPSs and effectively enhancing the overall performance of the battery. The principle of LiPSs conversion adsorption catalyzed by the CoS2/MoS2@HCS sulfur host material is illustrated in Fig. 6i. The ultrahigh specific surface area of HCS not only enhances electron/ion transfer rate and sulfur utilization but also effectively mitigates damage to the electrode material caused by sulfur volume expansion during the charge/discharge cycles of the battery. Compared to CoS2 and MoS2, the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction provides a greater number of active catalytic sites, significantly enhancing the adsorption capacity for LiPSs and promoting their effective conversion. The strong anchoring ability for LiPSs, accelerated interfacial charge transfer, and promotion of redox kinetics collectively contribute to improved sulfur utilization, electrochemical performance, and cycling stability of the battery. 3 Conclusions In summary, CoS2/MoS2 heterojunctions supported on hollow carbon spheres were carefully synthesized through calcination and hydrothermal reactions. Benefiting from the structural advantages and high catalytic performance of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction, the CoS2/MoS2@HCS demonstrates high adaptability to volumetric changes, strong polysulfide adsorption ability, and rapid catalytic conversion of LiPSs. Both computational and experimental results indicate that the local electric field formed by the CoS2 and MoS2 composite enhances interfacial effects, accelerates electron transfer between interfaces, improves the electrical conductivity of the electrode material, and enhances the adsorption capacity for LiPSs. The Li-S batteries with S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS composites as the cathode exhibit excellent performance in terms of discharge specific capacity, testing current, sulfur loading, and long-cycle stability. Soft-pack batteries based on S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS further validate their feasibility and practicality. This work provides valuable insights for the design of catalysts with high sulfur utilization and excellent electrocatalytic conversion performance in Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: The practical application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries is hindered by the sluggish redox kinetics of sulfur, significant volume expansion, and the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). To address these challenges, this study utilizes hollow carbon spheres (HCS) as a matrix, incorporating a heterojunction of transition metal sulfides (CoS2/MoS2) as the sulfur host. The HCS, with their ultrahigh specific surface area, effectively mitigate structural damage to the cathode caused by sulfur’s volume expansion during charge and discharge cycles. Meanwhile, the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction provides abundant chemical adsorption and reaction sites, which accelerate the redox kinetics of sulfur and alleviating the shuttle effect of LiPSs. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the coupling effect at the CoS2/MoS2 heterointerface significantly enhances charge transfer and adsorption interactions between CoS2/MoS2 and LiPSs. Experimental results demonstrate that Li-S batteries with S/CoS2/MoS2@HCS composites as the cathode exhibit an exceptionally low capacity decay rate of only 0.023% per cycle after 1200 cycles at 2.0 C. Even with high sulfur loading (7.9 mg cm−2) and a low electrolyte-to-sulfur (E/S) ratio (6.0 μL mg−1), the battery achieves an outstanding areal capacity of 6.86 mA h cm−2. This study develops a highly efficient CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction within HCS for the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs, providing valuable insights into the design of high-performance cathode materials for Li-S batteries.
